body_text.text: Most combination therapies used to treat antiretroviral-naı¨ve and -experienced HIV-1 infected patients include at least two nucleoside reverse transcriptase (RT) inhibitors (NRTIs).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: NRTIs are analogs of 2 0 -deoxyribonucleosides that lack a 3 0 -OH group on the ribose sugar/pseudosugar.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Once metabolized by host cell kinases to their active triphosphate (TP) forms, they inhibit viral reverse transcription by acting as chain terminators of HIV-1 RT DNA synthesis (1).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Although combination therapies that contain two or more NRTIs have substantially reduced mortality from HIV-1 associated disease, the approved NRTIs have significant limitations that include acute and chronic toxicity, and the selection of drug-resistant variants of HIV-1 that exhibit cross-resistance to other NRTIs.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Accordingly, there is a need to develop potent and safe NRTIs that demonstrate activity against a broad-range of drugresistant HIV-1.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To date, most NRTIs were discovered by an empirical approach in which novel sugar modified nucleoside analogs were synthesized without a priori knowledge of their activity against wild-type (WT) or drug-resistant HIV-1.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To specifically identify NRTIs that retain activity against a broad spectrum of drug-resistant HIV-1, our group adopted a rational discovery approach that utilized structure-activity-resistance relationships to identify NRTI base and sugar moieties that retain potent activity against drug-resistant HIV-1 (2,3).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Importantly, this approach identified 3 0 -azido-2 0 ,3 0 -dideoxyguanosine (3 0 -azido-ddG) as a lead compound (4) that exhibits potent activity against HIV-1 variants that contain the discrimination mutations K65R, L74V or M184V and against HIV-1 that contains multiple thymidine analog mutations (TAMs) that enhance nucleotide excision.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Furthermore, 3 0 -azido-ddG does not exhibit cytotoxicity in primary lymphocytes or epithelial and T-cell lines, and does not decrease the mitochondrial DNA content of HepG2 cells (4).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To further improve the antiviral activity of 3 0 -azido-ddG, we recently synthesized and characterized a series of novel base modified 3 0 -azido-2 0 ,3 0 -dideoxypurine analogs (5).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Of the 26 analogs studied, five [namely, 3 0 -azido-2 0 ,3 0 -dideoxy-2,6-diaminopurine (3 0 -azido-2, 6-DA-P), 3 0 -azido-2 0 ,3 0 -dideoxy-2-amino-6-chloropurine (3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P), 3 0 -azido-2 0 ,3 0 -dideoxy -2-amino-6-N, N-dimethylaminopurine (3 0 -azido-6-DM-P), 3 0 -azido-2 0 , 3 0 -dideoxy-2-amino-6-methoxypurine (3 0 -azido-6-MX-P) and 3 0 -azido-2 0 ,3 0 -dideoxy-2-amino-6-N-allylaminopurine (3 0 -azido-6-AA-P)] exhibited superior or equivalent activity to 3 0 -azido-ddG in primary lymphocytes (Figure 1).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To gain additional insight into the structure-activity-resistance relationships of these compounds, we have now synthesized their TP forms and have assessed their ability to inhibit DNA synthesis by recombinant purified HIV-1 RT.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Importantly, we show for the first time that HIV-1 RT recognizes and incorporates these 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides as adenosine analogs.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: These findings reveal new avenues for developing novel ambiguous nucleoside analogs that could be used to treat HIV-1 infection.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The WT, K65R, L74V, M184V, A62V/V75I/F77L/ F116Y/Q151M, M41L/L210W/T215Y (TAM41) and D67N/K70R/T215F/K219Q (TAM67) HIV-1 RTs were purified as described previously (6,7).
body_text.section: Reagents

body_text.text: The protein concentration of the purified enzymes was determined spectrophotometrically at 280 nm using an extinction coefficient (e 280 ) of 260 450 M À1 cm À1 , and by Bradford protein assays (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA).
body_text.section: Reagents

body_text.text: The RNA-and DNA-dependent DNA polymerase activities of the purified WT and mutant enzymes were similar (data not shown).
body_text.section: Reagents

body_text.text: The triphosphate (TP) forms of each of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddG analogs were synthesized and purified using the methods of Ludwig and Eckstein (8).
body_text.section: Reagents

body_text.text: 3 0 -Azido-ddGTP, 3 0 -azido-ddATP, 3 0 -azido-ddCTP and zidovudine-TP (ZDV-TP) were purchased from TriLink Biotechnologies, Inc. (San Diego, CA, USA).
body_text.section: Reagents

body_text.text: [g-32 P]ATP was obtained from PerkinElmer Life Sciences (Boston, MA, USA).

body_text.text: All DNA oligonucleotides were synthesized by Integrated DNA Technologies (Coralville, IA, USA).

body_text.text: The ability of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs to inhibit HIV-1 RT DNA-or RNA-dependent DNA synthesis was determined using two different template/primer (T/P) substrates, as described below:

body_text.text: (i) RT DNA synthesis was evaluated using a 214-nt RNA or DNA template that corresponds to the HIV-1 sequence used for (À) strong stop DNA synthesis Figure 2).

body_text.text: HIV-1 RT (200 nM) was pre-incubated with 20 nM T/P substrate, prior to rapid mixing with nucleotide and divalent metal ions to initiate the reaction that was quenched with 50 mM EDTA.

body_text.text: The disappearance of substrate (20mer) and the formation of product (21-mer) were quantified using a Bio-Rad GS525 Molecular Imager (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc., Hercules, CA, USA).

body_text.text: Data were fitted by nonlinear regression with Sigma Plot software (Systat Software, Inc., San Jose, CA, USA) using the appropriate equations (9).

body_text.text: The apparent burst rate constant (k obs ) for each particular concentration of dNTP was determined by fitting the time courses for the formation of product (21mer) using the following equation: [21mer] = A[1 À exp(Àk obs t)], where A represents the burst amplitude.
body_text.section: Inhibition of HIV-1 RT DNA synthesis under steady-state conditions by the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs

body_text.text: The turnover number (k pol ) and apparent dissociation constant for dNTP (K d ) were then obtained by plotting the apparent catalytic rates (k obs ) against dNTP concentrations and fitting the data with the following hyperbolic equation: k obs = (k pol [dNTP])/([dNTP]+K d ).

body_text.text: Catalytic efficiency was calculated as the ratio of turnover number over dissociation constant ([k pol /K d ]).

body_text.text: The ability of WT or TAM-containing HIV-1 RT to facilitate ATP-mediated excision of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddG-MP analogs from a DNA/DNA chain-terminated T/P was assessed as described previously (3).

body_text.text: For excision of 3 0 -azido-ddAMP and each 6-modified-3 0azido-ddGMP analog the T/P pair was T1/pr23A (pr23A: 5 0 -TTGTAGCACCATCCAAAGGTCTG-3 0 ).
body_text.section: Inhibition of HIV-1 RT DNA synthesis under steady-state conditions by the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs

body_text.text: The 23-nt DNA primer was 5 0 -radiolabeled with [g-32 P]ATP, annealed to T1, and then chain-terminated with the appropriate nucleotide analog.

body_text.text: Reactions were carried out in a 50-mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5) buffer that contained 50 mM KCl, 10 mM MgCl 2 , 3 mM ATP and Nucleotide analog The rate of incorporation was so inefficient that accurate kinetic parameters could not be determined.

body_text.text: 1 mM dATP/10 mM ddGTP.

body_text.text: Reactions were initiated by the addition of 200 nM WT or mutant RT.
body_text.section: Inhibition of HIV-1 RT DNA synthesis under steady-state conditions by the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs

body_text.text: Aliquots (5 ml) were removed at defined times, quenched with gel loading buffer, denatured at 95 C for 10 min, and product was then resolved from substrate by denaturing PAGE and analyzed, as described above.
body_text.section: Inhibition of HIV-1 RT DNA synthesis under steady-state conditions by the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs

body_text.text: Molecular models of incorporation were constructed using the X-ray crystallographic coordinates (PDB entry 1 RTD) for the RT-T/P-TTP ternary complex (10).
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: The 3 0 -OH of the primer strand as well as the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-2 0 ,3-ddGTP analogs and complementary bases in the template strand were built into the model to generate a pre-initiation complex, as described previously (11).
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: Tautomerization and protonation potential of the entire system was calculated using the Generalized Born/Volume Integral (GB/VI) electrostatics method of Labute (12).
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: Energy gradient minimization was carried out using MMFF94x force field in the Molecular Operating Environment (MOE 2008.02; Chemical Computing Group, Montreal, Quebec, Canada).
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: Ligand interactions were quantified and images generated using the LigX interaction function in MOE.
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: Structural models comparing incorporation and excision of specific nucleotide analogs used the PDB co-ordinates 3KLF and 3KLE that contain the excision product AZT adenosine dinucleoside tetraphosphate (AZTppppA) (13).
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: To eliminate the potential force field bias from alignment of bases, empirically derived angle relations were used for all analogs tested.
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: 3KLF and 3KLE were fit to the p66 subunit of 1RTD using the Matchmaker function in Chimera version 1.51 (UCSF Chimera, Resource for Biocomputing, Visualization, and Informatics at the University of California, San Francisco).
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

entity_spans.rawForm: UCSF Chimera, Resource for Biocomputing, Visualization, and Informatics at the University of California

body_text.text: Aligned structures were opened in MOE and dihedral angles were measured from bases relative to the ribose ring O and C1 of both template and bound nucleotides for each complex.
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: MOE's builder function was used to modify each template/bound nucleotide base pair retaining the experimental dihedrals.
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: Hydrogen-bonding potential between the aligned base pairs was quantified using the 'FindHBond' function in Chimera with default settings.
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: Parts of modeling workflow was automated using Pipeline Pilot 7.5 (Accelrys Corporation, San Diego, CA, USA)
body_text.section: Molecular modeling

body_text.text: To characterize the ability of the WT HIV-1 RT to incorporate the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs we first conducted steady-state DNA synthesis reactions using heteropolymeric DNA/DNA and RNA/DNA T/P substrates ( Figure 2).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: The sequences of the RNA and DNA templates correspond to the HIV-1 sequence used for (À) strong stop DNA synthesis, and both reactions were primed with the same 18-nt DNA primer that was complementary to the HIV-1 primer binding site (3).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: 3 0 -Azido-ddGTP, 3 0 -azido-ddATP, 3 0 -azido-ddCTP and ZDV-TP were included as controls in these experiments.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: Unexpectedly, we found that HIV-1 RT recognized all of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides as adenosine analogs and incorporated them opposite thymine in DNA (Figure 2A) or uracil in RNA ( Figure 2B).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: As anticipated, their incorporation resulted in chain-termination of DNA synthesis.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: Under the assay conditions described in Figure 2, the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides were not incorporated into the nascent DNA opposite cytosine.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: However, if the dNTP concentration was lowered to 0.1 mM, chain termination opposite cytosine was observed (data not shown).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: We also determined the concentration of 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analog required to inhibit DNA synthesis (i.e. IC 50 ) using a different heteropolymeric DNA/DNA T/P substrate, as described in the 'Materials and Methods' section ( Table 2).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: Their order of potency against WT RT was determined to be: 3 0 -azido-ddATP, 3 0 -azido-ddGTP >3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP > 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-TP, 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P-TP > 3 0 -azido-6-DM-P-TP, 3 0 -azido-6-MX-P-TP.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: Pre-steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT Pre-steady-state kinetic analyses were carried out to elucidate, in detail, the interactions between the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs and the polymerase active site of WT HIV-1 RT (Table 1).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: Because the 6-modified-3 0azido-ddGTP analogs behave as adenine nucleotide analogs, we included 3 0 -azido-ddATP as a control.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: The results (Table 1) show that the catalytic efficiency of incorporation (k pol /K d ) of 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP was similar to that of dATP and 3 0 -azido-ddATP.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: Consistent with the steady-state kinetic experiments, 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-TP, 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P-TP and 3 0 -azido-6-MX-P-TP were all less efficiently incorporated by WT HIV-1 compared to dATP.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: The observed decreases in catalytic efficiency for each of these substrates was driven by both a decrease in the rate of nucleotide incorporation (i.e. k pol ) and a decrease in the affinity of the nucleotide for the polymerase active site (i.e. K d ).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: Due to limited quantities of the 3 0 -azido-6-DM-P-TP, we were unable to obtain pre-steady-state kinetic data for this analog.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: We also assessed the ability of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs to be incorporated opposite cytosine ( Table 1).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: The data show that, in comparison to dGTP, the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs were inefficiently incorporated by HIV-1 RT.
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: The only compound with reasonable activity as a G-analog was 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-TP; however, its selectivity value versus dGTP (254) was $7-fold less than its selectivity value versus dATP (35).
body_text.section: Steady-state incorporation of 6-modified 3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides by HIV-1 RT

body_text.text: The amino acid substitutions K65R, L74V, Q151M (in complex with A62V, V75I, F77L and F116Y) or M184V in HIV-1 RT improve the enzyme's ability to discriminate between the natural dNTP substrate and an NRTI-TP.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: These substitutions are typically referred to as NRTI discrimination mutations.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: To determine whether NRTI discrimination mutations impacted RTs' ability to recognize and incorporate the 6-modified-ddGTP analogs, we determined the concentration of nucleotide analog required to inhibit 50% of the DNA polymerase activity (i.e. IC 50 ) under steady-state assay conditions using the heteropolymeric DNA/DNA T/P substrates as described in the 'Materials and Methods' section ( Table 2).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: 3 0 -Azido-ddATP, 3 0 -azido-ddGTP and ZDV-TP were again included as controls.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: The 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs were also incorporated as adenosine analogs by the mutant HIV-1 RTs (data not shown).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: In general, the mutant HIV-1 RTs exhibited fold-resistance values to each of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs that were similar (i.e. <2-fold) to the fold change in resistance values determined for 3 0 -azido-ddATP.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: The only statistically significant exceptions (P < 0.05) included 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P-TP and 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP which exhibited better activity against K65R HIV-1 RT and M184V HIV-1 RT, respectively.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Of interest, the fold-resistance values for all of the 3 0 -azido-dideoxypurines against HIV-1 RT containing A62V/V75I/F77L/Y116F/Q151M were significantly less than the fold-resistance value that was determined for ZDV-TP.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Excision of 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddG-5 0 -MP analogs by WT and TAM containing HIV-1 RT HIV-1 RT has the intrinsic ability to rescue DNA synthesis from an NRTI-MP blocked primer, using ATP as a phosphate donor (14).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: This ATP-mediated excision activity of HIV-1 RT is selectively increased by TAMs (15).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Accordingly, we investigated the ability of WT and TAM-containing RT to excise the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGMP analogs from a DNA chain-terminated T/P.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Two RT enzymes that contained different patterns of TAMs [e.g. D67N/K70R/T215F/K219Q (TAM67) and M41L/L210W/T215Y (TAM41)] were studied.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Our results (Figure 3) showed that the WT, TAM67, and TAM41 RTs could unblock T/Ps chain-terminated with 3 0 -azido-ddAMP, 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-MP and 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P-MP, although TAM41 RT and TAM67 RT were more efficient in this regard than was the WT enzyme.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: By contrast, both the WT and TAM-containing RTs could not efficiently unblock T/P substrates chain-terminated with 3 0 -azido-6-MX-P-MP, 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-MP or 3 0 -azido-6-DM-P-MP.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Molecular models of 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP and 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-TP in the active site of HIV-1 RT
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: We used molecular modeling to gain structural insight into the binding interaction between the 6-modified-3 0azido-ddGTP analogs and the thymine base in the DNA template in the active site of HIV-1 RT.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Specifically we modeled 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP and 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-TP into the active site of HIV-1 RT using the co-ordinates (1RTD) from the RT-T/P-TTP complex (10).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Both 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP and 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-TP were found to fit comfortably into the active site of HIV-1 RT and formed hydrogen-bond interactions with the thymine base in the DNA template (Figure 4).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: However, the base hydrogen-bonding characteristics differed for each analog.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: The base of 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P-TP forms two hydrogen-bond interactions through the nitrogen (NH) at position 1 and the amine (NH 2 ) at position 2 with the template thymine ( Figure 4B).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: In addition to these two hydrogen-bonding interactions, 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP can form an additional hydrogen bond via the amino group (NH 2 ) at the 6-position of the purine base ( Figure 4D).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Therefore, the 2,6-diaminopurine:thymine base-pairing interaction mimics the canonical Watson-Crick guanine:cytidine interaction.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Molecular models for ATP-mediated excision of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddG-5 0 -MP analogs To gain structural insight into why the 6-modified-3 0azido-ddG analogs are differentially excised by HIV-1 RT containing TAMs, we modeled their excision products (6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddG adenosine dinucleoside tetraphosphate) in the enzyme's active site.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: These models reveal a hydrogen-bonding network that is different from those observed for the TP forms.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: 3 0 -Azido-ddA forms hydrogen bonds from the 1 and 6 atoms to the 3 and 4 atoms of the complementary thymine template in both the incorporation ( Figure 4C) and excision ( Figure 5A) models.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: By contrast, the hydrogen bond observed between the 2-amino substitution and the 2-carbonyl of the thymine template observed for the nucleotide triphosphate analogs ( Figure 4B and D) is lost in all related excision complexes ( Figure 5B-D).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P ( Figure 5B) and 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P ( Figure 5C) retain an H-bond from the 6 atom position of the purine ring and the 4 atom position on the template thymine, whereas this interaction is not maintained for 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P ( Figure 5D), 3 0 -azido-6-DM-P and 3 0 -azido-6-MX-P (data not shown).
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: Taken together, these different hydrogen-bonding patterns may explain why 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P and 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P are more efficiently excised by HIV-1 RT than are 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P, 3 0 -azido-6-DM-P and 3 0 -azido-6-MX-P.
body_text.section: Activity of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs against HIV-1 RT containing NRTI discrimination mutations

body_text.text: In this study, we demonstrated that 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotides act as adenosine mimetics for DNA synthesis carried out by HIV-1 RT.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Of the five analogs studied, 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP, which has a 2,6-diaminopurine base, was found to be the most efficient substrate for incorporation by HIV-1 RT.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In pre-steady-state kinetic experiments, 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP was recognized and incorporated by WT HIV-1 RT as efficiently as dATP and 3 0 -azido-ddATP.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The analogs that contain the 2-amino-6-N,N-dimethylaminopurine (3 0 -azido-6-DM-P-TP) or 2-amino-6-methoxypurine (3 0 -azido-6-MX-P-TP) bases, however, were poor substrates for incorporation by HIV-1 RT.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our molecular modeling studies suggest that 6-modifications with a branched side-chain (e.g. 3 0 -azido-6-DM-P-TP) or one with electronic incompatibility (e.g. 3 0 -azido-6-MX-P-TP) may alter the alignment of the bases and move their a-phosphate away from the primer 3 0 -OH, thus impairing nucleotide incorporation.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In contrast, 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP, 3 0 -azido-6-CL-P-TP and 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P-TP form relatively planar basepairing interactions with the template thymine that enhance their a-phosphate interaction with the 3 0 -OH of the primer.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Compared to the canonical A:T base pair, the additional hydrogen bond achieved by the 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P:thymine base pair may further stabilize the a-phosphate, facilitating the favorable catalytic efficiency observed in pre-steady-state assays.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In contrast, the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP nucleotide analogs are inefficiently incorporated by HIV-1 RT opposite cytosine bases.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Taken together, these findings are consistent with those of Cheong et al. who reported that oligodeoxyribonucleotide duplexes containing 2,6-diaminopurine formed more stable base pairs opposite thymine than cytosine (16).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The mutations K65R, L74V, Q151M (in complex with A62V, V75I, F77L and F116Y) or M184V in HIV-1 RT allow the enzyme to discriminate between the natural dNTP substrate and modified nucleotide analogs.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In Table 2, we show that the K65R, L74V and Q151M mutations confer low levels of resistance to both 3 0 -azido-ddATP and 3 0 -azido-ddGTP at the enzyme level.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Modification at the 6-position of the purine base does not appear to enhance this discrimination phenotype: the K65R, L74V or A62V/V75I/F77L/F116Y/Q151M HIV-1 RTs all exhibited fold-resistance changes to each of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGTP analogs that were largely similar (i.e. <2-fold) to the fold change in resistance values determined for 3 0 -azido-ddATP.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Interestingly, the structure-activity relationship for the ATP-mediated excision of the 6-modified-3 0 -azido-ddGMP analogs by WT or TAM-containing HIV-1 RT differed from the structure-activity relationship for their incorporation.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: For example, whereas 3 0 -azido-6-CL-P-TP is a relatively good substrate for incorporation, it is not efficiently excised by either WT or TAM-containing HIV-1 RT.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In this regard, our modeling data show that the hydrogenbonding patterns observed for this analog differs from that of 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P and 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P ( Figure 5).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: As such, it is possible that the change in transition state geometry required for excision is not sufficiently stabilized by the 6-Cl substituted guanine analog base-paired with thymine.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Taken together, these data suggest that the optimal conformation of the HIV-1 RT active site differs for incorporation and excision and further suggests that 6-position modifications differentially effect these two reactions.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This finding provides 'proof of concept' that modified base analogs can be identified that are efficiently incorporated by HIV-1 RT but serve as a poor substrate for HIV-1 ATP-mediated excision reactions.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Further optimization of these Figure 5.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Molecular models of the excision products of 3 0 -azido-ddA (A), 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P (B), 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P (C) and 3 0 -azido-6-Cl-P (D) in the DNA polymerase active site of HIV-1 RT containing TAMs.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Each of the analogs was modeled into the ternary RT-T/P-AZTppppA complex (pdb co-ordinates 3KLE).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: A schematic representation of the hydrogen-bonding patterns between the excised nucleotide analog and the template base is depicted below each model.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: divergent but favorable properties of purine analogs is in progress.

We previously demonstrated that 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P, 3 0 -azido-6-CL-P, 3 0 -azido-6-DM-P, 3 0 -azido-6-MX-P and 3 0 -azido-6-AA-P showed comparable or superior antiviral activities to 3 0 -azido-ddG in primary human cells (5, Figure 1).
Intracellular pharmacology analyses, however, revealed that each of these compounds was efficiently metabolized by adenosine deaminase to 3 0 -azido-ddG in cells (5).
Therefore, the observed anti-HIV-1 activity of each of these nucleoside analogs was not primarily due to incorporation of the ambiguous purine nucleotides described in this study.

However, we recently identified RS-788, a 5 0 -monophosphate prodrug of 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P, as a potent and selective inhibitor of HIV-1 replication (Schinazi et al., 16th Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections (2009) Abstract 557).
In peripheral blood mononuclear cells, RS-788 is metabolized $1:1 to both 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP and 3 0 -azido-ddGTP.

Consequently, RS-788 delivers two chemically distinct metabolites each of which are potent HIV-1 RT chain terminators that are incorporated opposite different complementary bases (cytosine for 3 0 -azido-ddGTP and thymine for 3 0 -azido-2,6-DA-P-TP).
Therefore, our studies provide a promising new approach for the design and development of novel ambiguous NRTI that exert profound antiviral activity against WT and drug-resistant HIV-1.
